Knit to Fit
A Comprehensive Guide to Hand and Machine Knitting
BY IDA RILEY DUNCAN
Foremost Authority and Consultant on Construction and Style in Knitting,
Ass’t Prof., Home Economics, Wayne State University.
Includes the complete 49-lesson course of Mrs. Duncan’s Progressive School of
Knitting Design, covering every phase of scientific knitting—hand and machine
—clearly outlined, diagrammed and illustrated, a truly scientific, exclusive for¬
mula-method for perfect fit for any type of knitwear.
“Mrs. Duncan’s book offers a good basic course in designing knits for
either hand-knitting or machine work. This is a good basic work for
needlework collections.”
LIBRARY JOURNAL,—Nadine Harkins, Southern Oregon College.
“A discussion of color suitability and changing colors will help those
who lack an awareness of color as a factor in the becomingness of cloth¬
ing .. . Instructions for knitting with ribbon are also given. —Rosa
Jean Tannahill, Head of the Dept, of Home Economics, Lamar State
College of Technology.

Thomas Jefferson Apostle of Liberty
BY MARGUERITE E. WILBUR
Author of: John Sutter, Journal of Madame Giovanni (Trans.), etc.
Discloses the more intimate, personal aspects of Jefferson’s life his joys and
sorrows, ambitions, ideals, theories, his inner thoughts from whose dynamic roots
grew the greatness of America. Interwoven with the political pageant of his age
are the leading men with whom he was closely associated—Patrick Henry, George
Washington, Henry Adams, Alexander Hamilton, Lafayette, and many more.
“There is a cumulative radiance in the book that makes this biography
far out of the ordinary. Thomas Jefferson was indeed Ae Apostle ot
Liberty — now I am sure of it.” — Dr. Daniel A. Poling, Editor
THE CHRISTIAN HERALD.
“Marguerite Wilbur’s THOMAS JEFFERSON is a swift-paced sympa¬
thetic portrait, which should enjoy a wide readership -Richard B.
